``` 2. **`

``` 6. **`

title: HTML Lists
content:
In HTML, lists are used to group and organize content. There are two main types of lists: ordered lists and unordered lists. ## Unordered Lists Unordered lists are used when the order of the list items is not important. They are created using the `
    ` element, with each item inside the list represented by an `
  • ` element. ### Basic Syntax ```html
    • Item 1
    • Item 2
    • Item 3
    ``` ### Example ```html
    • Apples
    • Oranges
    • Bananas
    ``` This will create a bulleted list with three items. ## Ordered Lists Ordered lists are used when the order of the list items is important. They are created using the `
      ` element, with each item inside the list represented by an `
    1. ` element. ### Basic Syntax ```html
      1. First item
      2. Second item
      3. Third item
      ``` ### Example ```html
      1. First step
      2. Second step
      3. Third step
      ``` This will create a numbered list with three items. ## Nested Lists You can also nest lists inside one another to create sub-lists: ### Example ```html
      • Fruits
        • Apples
        • Oranges
      • Vegetables
        • Carrots
        • Spinach
      ``` ## Styling Lists You can style lists using CSS to change the appearance of bullets or numbers: ### Example ```css ul { list-style-type: square; } ol { list-style-type: upper-roman; } ``` ### Conclusion Lists are a fundamental part of HTML and are essential for organizing content on web pages. Understanding how to use and style them effectively will enhance the readability and structure of your content.

title: HTML Forms
content:
Forms are used to collect user input on web pages. In HTML, forms are created using the `<form>` tag and include various input elements to gather data from users.

## Basic Syntax

The basic structure of a form is:

```html
<form action="/submit-form" method="post">
  <!-- Form elements go here -->
</form>
```

- `action` attribute: Specifies the URL where the form data will be sent when submitted.
- `method` attribute: Defines the HTTP method used to send form data. Common methods are `get` and `post`.

## Form Elements

### Text Input

To create a single-line text input field, use the `<input>` tag with the `type` attribute set to `text`:

```html
<form>
  <label for="name">Name:</label>
  <input type="text" id="name" name="name">
</form>
```

### Password Input

For password fields, use the `type` attribute set to `password`:

```html
<form>
  <label for="password">Password:</label>
  <input type="password" id="password" name="password">
</form>
```

### Radio Buttons

To create a group of radio buttons, use the `type` attribute set to `radio`:

```html
<form>
  <label><input type="radio" name="gender" value="male"> Male</label>
  <label><input type="radio" name="gender" value="female"> Female</label>
</form>
```

### Checkboxes

For checkboxes, use the `type` attribute set to `checkbox`:

```html
<form>
  <label><input type="checkbox" name="subscribe"> Subscribe to newsletter</label>
</form>
```

### Dropdown Menu

To create a dropdown menu, use the `<select>` element with `<option>` elements:

```html
<form>
  <label for="color">Choose a color:</label>
  <select id="color" name="color">
    <option value="red">Red</option>
    <option value="green">Green</option>
    <option value="blue">Blue</option>
  </select>
</form>
```

### Submit Button

To submit the form, use the `<button>` or `<input>` tag with `type` set to `submit`:

```html
<form>
  <input type="submit" value="Submit">
</form>
```

## Form Validation

HTML5 provides built-in form validation features. For example, using the `required` attribute ensures that a field must be filled out before submission:

```html
<form>
  <label for="email">Email:</label>
  <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>
  <input type="submit" value="Submit">
</form>
```

## Conclusion

Forms are a vital part of web applications, allowing users to interact and provide information. Understanding the different types of input elements and validation techniques helps in creating effective forms.

title: HTML Media
content:
HTML provides various elements for embedding media content, including audio and video. These elements allow you to include multimedia in your web pages.

## Audio

The `<audio>` element is used to embed sound files. It supports multiple formats including MP3, WAV, and Ogg.

### Basic Syntax

```html
<audio controls>
  <source src="audio-file.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
```

- `controls` attribute: Adds playback controls such as play, pause, and volume.
- `<source>` element: Specifies the audio file and its format.

### Example

```html
<audio controls>
  <source src="https://www.example.com/audio.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
```

## Video

The `<video>` element is used to embed video files. It supports formats like MP4, WebM, and Ogg.

### Basic Syntax

```html
<video width="640" height="360" controls>
  <source src="video-file.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
```

- `width` and `height` attributes: Define the dimensions of the video player.
- `controls` attribute: Adds playback controls such as play, pause, and volume.
- `<source>` element: Specifies the video file and its format.

### Example

```html
<video width="640" height="360" controls>
  <source src="https://www.example.com/video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
```

## Media Attributes

### `autoplay`

Automatically starts playing the media when it is loaded:

```html
<audio autoplay>
  <source src="audio-file.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
</audio>
```

### `loop`

Loops the media continuously:

```html
<video loop>
  <source src="video-file.mp4" type="video/mp4">
</video>
```

### `muted`

Mutes the media by default:

```html
<video muted>
  <source src="video-file.mp4" type="video/mp4">
</video>
```

## Conclusion

Embedding media in your web pages enriches the user experience by providing interactive and engaging content. Proper use of the `<audio>` and `<video>` elements allows you to incorporate various types of multimedia seamlessly.

title: HTML Semantics
content:
Semantic HTML refers to using HTML elements that convey meaning about the content they enclose. These elements help improve the accessibility and SEO of web pages by providing meaningful structure to the content. ## What is Semantic HTML? Semantic HTML elements clearly describe their meaning in a human- and machine-readable way. They make it easier for search engines and other user agents to understand the structure and importance of the content. ## Common Semantic Elements ### `
` Defines a header for a document or section. Typically contains introductory content or navigational links: ```html

Website Title

  • Home
  • About
``` ### `
` Defines a footer for a document or section. Often contains information about the author, copyright, or contact details: ```html

© 2024 Your Website

Contact Us

``` ### `
` Defines independent, self-contained content. Suitable for blog posts, news articles, or user comments: ```html

Article Title

Article content goes here...

``` ### `
` Defines a section in a document. Used to group related content within an article or a page: ```html

Section Title

Section content goes here...

``` ### `
` Defines content that is tangentially related to the content around it. Often used for sidebars or additional information: ```html

Related Information

Additional content or links related to the main content.

``` ### `
` Defines navigation links. Typically used for menus and site navigation: ```html
  • Home
  • Services
  • Contact
``` ## Benefits of Semantic HTML 1. **Improved Accessibility**: Screen readers and other assistive technologies can better interpret the content structure. 2. **Better SEO**: Search engines can more accurately index and rank content based on its meaning and structure. 3. **Cleaner Code**: Semantic elements make the HTML more readable and maintainable. 4. **Enhanced User Experience**: Provides a clearer structure that benefits both users and developers. ## Conclusion Using semantic HTML elements enhances the clarity and accessibility of web content, leading to a better user experience and improved search engine performance.
